greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ βληθὲν ἔξω καταπατεῖσθαι ὑπὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων

english:
NLT:
p: (if you ignore the least commandment
and teach others to do the same)
q: (you will be called least in the Kingdom of Heaven)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "whoever..."
NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: "if you"
notes:
Greek: ος εαν 'whoever'
This verse (and also Mat 12:32; 16:25; 18:5-6; 20:26-27) compares two different kinds of people. The first kind of person is referred to with the relative pronoun ος and εαν, while the second type of person is referred to with the relative pronoun ος and αν; both mean "whoever". (Parallel passages in Mark's gospel use αν in both clauses.) It is possible in English to treat this as a true conditional and translate "if anyone" or to personalize it, as in the NLT: "if you".

english:
p: (if it be possible)
q: (let this cup pass from me)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if...possible"
notes:
It seems unlikely that Jesus would have prayed in such a way if he didn't believe there was some possibility - even a very unlikely possibility - that God could take the cup of suffering from him. Alternatively, this could be a politeness strategy. Translator's Notes points out that Jesus is not asking about whether or not it is possible for God (because all things are possible for God) but rather Jesus is requesting God change his plans.
See "if possible" constructions.

NLT: untranslated
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'except'
Although Boyer (1982b:168; 1983:182) claims that this is a true conditional, here it merely means "except", as seen by the close parallel with ἀλλα in the second half of the verse.
Paraphrases (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): 
NIV: For whatever is hidden is meant to be disclosed, and whatever is concealed is meant to be brought out into the open.
NLT: For everything that is hidden will eventually be brought into the open, and every secret will be brought to light.

greek_protases.p1: ὅπου ἐὰν εἰσέλθῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: εἴπατε τῷ οἰκοδεσπότῃ ὅτι Ὁ διδάσκαλος λέγει, Ποῦ ἐστιν τὸ κατάλυμά μου ὅπου τὸ πάσχα μετὰ τῶν μαθητῶν μου φάγω;

english:
p: (if it were possible)
q: (the hour might pass from him)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if...possible"
notes:
Boyer notes that this is "not a complete conditional sentence, but an idiomatic parenthetic insertion into a purpose clause" (1981: 87). Here, the insertion of "if possible" seems to express unlikeliness rather than impossibility. (Note how Luke's account has "if willing" functioning the same way and supporting this analysis.) According to this view, Jesus would not have prayed in this way unless he believed there was a possibility, however remote, of its fulfillment. 
Alternatively, Cole argues that while Jesus knows that God can do anything, he also knows that it is indeed impossible for the Messiah to avoid suffering. Translator's Notes states that "if possible" is a mark of Jesus's humility in asking this of the Father; that is, it is a politeness/humility strategy.
See also "if possible" constructions.

english:
p: (whoever receives this child in my name)

p: (and whoever receives me)

english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes:
Greek:  ὃς ἐὰν "whoever".
This verse (and also Luk 17:33) compares two different kinds of people. The first kind of person is referred to with the relative pronoun ὃς and ἐὰν, while the second type of person is referred to with the relative pronoun ὃς and ἂν; both mean "whoever". It is possible in English to treat this as a true conditional and translate "if anyone" or, as in the NLT, to personalize it, "if you".

greek_protases.p1: ἐπεὶ καὶ σὺ ἐκκοπήσῃ

english:
p: (if possible)
so far as it depends on you, live peaceably with all
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: not translated
notes:
εἰ δυνατὸν 'if possible'
This is acknowledging the unlikeliness (or impossibility) of living at peace with everyone entirely, since such a thing depends on others "living at peace" as well. The secondary, explanatory caveat "as far as it depends on you," is not what is modified by "if possible." Rather, it is the command to "live at peace" that is modified by both "if possible" and "as far as it depends on you." This additional modifying phrase is what makes this command more likely to be fulfilled than other "if possible" constructions.
See "if possible"constructions

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἐν τῷ σταυρῷ τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ

english:
NASB:
p: (if indeed you have heard of the stewardship of God’s grace which was given to me for you...)
english_translations:
ESV, RSV, NLT: "assuming"
NASB: "if indeed"
NRSV: "for surely"
NIV: "surely"
notes:
εἴ γε 'if indeed'
Some commentators (Hoehner 2008; Arnold 2010) suggest that p consists of vs.2-12, and q is v.13. However, most translations do not treat this as a genuine conditional; Translator's Notes accepts the NIV's "surely" and states, "Paul was saying that he was sure that the Ephesian believers knew of his ministry of preaching the gospel."

greek_protases.p1: ἵνα εἴτε ἐλθὼν καὶ ἰδὼν ὑμᾶς εἴτε ἀπὼν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀκούω τὰ περὶ ὑμῶν, ὅτι στήκετε ἐν ἑνὶ πνεύματι, μιᾷ ψυχῇ συναθλοῦντες τῇ πίστει τοῦ εὐαγγελίου

english: p: (that by any means possible I may attain the resurrection from the dead)
english_translations:
ESV: "that by any means possible"
NASB: "in order that"
RSV: "that if possible"
NRSV: "if somehow"
NIV: "and so, somehow"
NLT: "so that one way or another"
notes:
Greek: ει πως + subjunctive ('if somehow I may')
The conditional is not "If I atttain resurrection from the dead" but "If there are any means possible by which I can attain resurrection of the dead" the latter which we know to be true. Thus Paul is not arguing that he has for certain gained resurrection from the dead, but that since it is a possibility he will do anything and everything to attain it.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ πως καταντήσω εἰς τὴν ἐξανάστασιν τὴν ἐκ νεκρῶν

NASB: "so that"
notes:
Greek εἰ καὶ 'even if, if indeed'
"it" refers to the righteousness which Paul talks about in 3:8-11, that he is working towards but has not yet attained.

NLT: "or... like"

greek_protases.p1: ὡς ἐὰν τροφὸς θάλπῃ τὰ ἑαυτῆς τέκνα

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀλλὰ ἐγενήθημεν νήπιοι ἐν μέσῳ ὑμῶν

english:
p: (whether we are awake or asleep)
q: ([Jesus] died for us so that ... we might live with him)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "whether... or"
notes:
εἴτε
The conditionals "if we are awake or if we are asleep..." state that being alive or asleep (i.e. dead) makes no difference; we will live with him in either case. This can be expressed in English as 'whether we are alive or asleep/dead' or 'even if we are alive and even if we are asleep, we will live with him.'
This is an ‘alternative concessive conditional’ construction, in which the two 'conditional' clauses present an exhaustive set of alternatives, in this case being alive or being dead.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε γρηγορῶμεν εἴτε καθεύδωμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔνδειγμα τῆς δικαίας κρίσεως τοῦ θεοῦ εἰς τὸ καταξιωθῆναι ὑμᾶς τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ, ὑπὲρ ἧς καὶ πάσχετε,

english_translations:

greek_apodoses.q1: στήκετε, καὶ κρατεῖτε τὰς παραδόσεις ἃς ἐδιδάχθητε

english:
q: (the law is not laid down for the just but for the lawless and disobedient, for the ungodly and the sinners, for the unholy and the profane, for those who strike their fathers and mothers, for murderers, the sexually immoral, men who practice homosexuality, enslavers, liars, perjurers)
p: (and whatever else is contrary to sound doctrine)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "whatever else"
NLT: "anything else"
notes: Greek: εἴ τι ἕτερον 'if any other thing'. This does not state a condition under which q holds, but rather ει τι functions as an indefinite pronoun. Similar to 2Co 2:10, 7:14.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι ἕτερον τῇ ὑγιαινούσῃ διδασκαλίᾳ ἀντίκειται

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰδὼς τοῦτο, ὅτι δικαίῳ νόμος οὐ κεῖται, ἀνόμοις δὲ καὶ ἀνυποτάκτοις, ἀσεβέσι καὶ ἁμαρτωλοῖς, ἀνοσίοις καὶ βεβήλοις, πατρολῴαις καὶ μητρολῴαις, ἀνδροφόνοις πόρνοις ἀρσενοκοίταις ἀνδραποδισταῖς ψεύσταις ἐπιόρκοις,

english:
NASB (following Greek closely):
p1: (if anyone competes as an athlete,)
q1: (q2: [he does not win the prize] p2: [unless he competes according to the rules.])

ESV: 
q: (An athlete is not crowned)
p: (unless he competes according to the rules)
english_translations:
ESV, NLT: no conditional / "unless"
NASB: "if anyone" / "unless"
NRSV: "in the case of" / "without"
NIV: "anyone who" / "except by"
notes:
This verse is grammatically complex because it has a conditional embedded within another conditional. Most translations simplify the grammar in some way. The first p seems to be presentational, introducing the topic of athletes, so in that sense, 2:5b-c is the true conditional (see ESV).
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless'):
p1 (if anyone competes as an athlete,) q1: (q2: [he wins the prize] p2: [only if he competes according to the rules.])
or:
q: (an athlete wins the prize) p: [only if he competes according to the rules.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ καὶ ἀθλῇ τις, … ἐὰν μὴ νομίμως ἀθλήσῃ

english:
p: (If we have died with him,)
q: (we will also live with him)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes:
The conditionals of 2:11-13 are a Christian hymn modified by Paul for this context, rather than a logical argument .
2Ti 2:11 is very similar to Rom 6:8. Given the connection with baptism in Romans 6, Paul's theology, and the fact that this p is in the aorist, this is clearly a factual conditional.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ συναπεθάνομεν,

english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes: Mounce (2000) claims that there is an implied warning in this verse. Unlike v.11, the final three conditionals in this hymn have a neutral probability.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὑπομένομεν

q: (he also will deny us;)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἀρνησόμεθα

q: (he remains faithful)

See note at 2:12b.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν τις ἐκκαθάρῃ ἑαυτὸν ἀπὸ τούτων,

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔσται σκεῦος εἰς τιμήν, ἡγιασμένον, εὔχρηστον τῷ δεσπότῃ, εἰς πᾶν ἔργον ἀγαθὸν ἡτοιμασμένον

english:

english_translations:

NASB: "if any man"
NRSV: "someone who"
NIV, NLT: no conditional, "an elder must..."
notes: Paul is giving Titus a guideline for appointing elders. This conditional lists the attributes of an elder; however, q is left implicit. The conditional expression εἴ τίς 'if anyone' can equally well be treated as an indefinite pronoun as in NRSV "someone".

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τίς ἐστιν ἀνέγκλητος, μιᾶς γυναικὸς ἀνήρ, τέκνα ἔχων πιστά, μὴ ἐν κατηγορίᾳ ἀσωτίας ἢ ἀνυπότακτα

english:

q: (receive him as you would receive me)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes: Philemon knows that Paul considers him a partner. Paul is making his request on the basis of that relationship.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ οὖν με ἔχεις κοινωνόν,

english:
p: (if he has wronged you at all, or owes you anything)
q: (charge that to my account)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes: Paul is sending Onesimus, a slave, back to Philemon, his master. It is highly likely that Philemon feels that Onesimus has done him wrong. By asking Philemon to charge everything owed to his (Paul's) account, Paul is taking on the responsibility for paying what Onesimus owes.
